Chungking
Nov. 3,
1938
Dear
Bix:
I am waiting here at the office for Francis Pan who promised to come
by to see me about
seven o'clock, and as I have over an hour I will start this
to you.
I tried
go out
to see Mr. Pan but he had to attend the Peoples Conference
which has
been going on here for several days, so he said he would drop in here
after it was over.
this Peoples Conference I am all for it.
It met in Maxgkax
Hankow about
three or
months ago and it brought forth some
very constructive
criticisms on the Ministry of Railways and Communications•
It had Dr. H.
on the carpet the
other day end grilled him for three hours. The point in dispute
was why he had placed his son David in charge of the Central Trust.
Conference is
composed
some of the ablest and most independent people in
Another item of
gossip around here
is that China and the Soviets are not
getting along too well at the moment and that China may more or
from Russia.
The Russians
seem to be getting much consideration from
anyone just now. Everyone seems to be climbing on the German band wagon.
Hoch der Hitler•
Anyway I hear Dr. Kung made a deal with the Soviets for
munitions in
agreed to pay for the
transportation in Sterling or
Pefused to pay except in Mex at the official rate. Unfortunately
the munitions were sold on credit which sort of cramped the Doctors style.
I have written Mr. Morgan all the official dope there is so I know you
are fairly well informed. I used the term advisedly because actually things are
in the deuce of a mess but I have tried not to make my letters to pessimistic
as I did not wish to appear to be doing too much complaining. I do enough as
it is.
The chief trouble is, I am afraid, that either I am not bearing down like I
should, or that I am getting
stale, or that I have been neglecting details too
much. Anyway now that Ixkaxa kad am having time to go into things more,
there are many
things which I have been overlooking and which I do not wish to
tackle. There
have been many occasions
when I have felt that I was neglecting
my work and there have been other occasions when I should have handled details
differently but did not because I was I was simply following the line of least
I do not think I have been working hard enough to hurt me and my living
conditions have been alright.
I think the main trouble is that there is never
a chance to let up and relax. And I have to confess that I have a strong urge
every now and then to see my Kid. It has been about fifteen months sined I saw
him and that is a long time at his age. I had had strong hopes of being able to
get home for Christmas but they are beginning to grow very dim although I have not
given them up entirely yet.
two operations problems, gasoline and spare parts, and we have one
political or business problem, the adjustment of routes between Eurasia and CNAC
now that
the available area has been so
greatly reduced.
Regarding the gas, we
have about one hundred and forty thousand gallons in Ichang and it looks like it
is going to
be a race between the Japanese
getting there end our getting it out.
Socony has a boat there ready which can carry forty thousand
gallons per trip but
